https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/76975/ : SUCCESS
Just one question on the error handling, but otherwise it looks good to me.
Should this be checking for EBADR here?

That is a good point, what if this interface doesn't exist. 
I think this should follow https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/63509dd54c3290750961899125d588ea5f339023/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp#L44

Why is this using the service name from the other call?  This should be using the result of a getSubTree call to determine the service name.  Doing this prevents breakages when interfaces are split across daemons.

Thanks for finding this.
It was a fabric adapter's serviceName (which is incorrect).
I fixed it to port's service (which is found during `getValidFabricPortPath()` in new code).
Please make this its own function.

Done.
Made it as a separate function `afterGetFabricPortLocation()`
re: the above, this is returning the service name of the ITEM interface, not the location interface.

Done.  
Changed the code to obtain  Port's serviceName (not as Fabric ServiceName) in `getValidFabricPortPath()` via `GetAssociatedSubTree()`
Please respond to all commits with a "Done" ("ack" is not the same)

Done.
Respond the comments with Done & explanation.
One the below is done, to use the subtree result properly, this can be a hard error.

Do you mean that ec.value() == EBADR is also a hard error?

The same style of the logic is already done for `getFabricAdapterLocation()` - https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/dfd5547b98d0a7360ca6cfe8b48b9d7ce2cf95d2/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp#L40C1-L62C2

If so, `getFabricAdapterLocation()` may also have the same issue?

This looks incorrect.  This is the serviceName of the service hosting the fabric adapter path, not the decorator path.  You need to put your call to this where you do the subtree call, and find the service hosting the Location interface, not the service hosting the fabric interface.  In your case, they're likely the same which is why you don't see that bug.
